Contents.Layers:
The eyelids act to protect the anterior surface of the globe from local injury. Additionally, they aid in regulation of light reaching the eye; in tear film maintenance, by distributing the protective and optically important tear film over the cornea during blinking; and in tear flow, by their pumping action on the conjunctival sac and lacrimal sac.

Structures that must be considered in a description of lid anatomy are the skin and subcutaneous tissue; the orbicularis oculi muscle (shown below); the submuscular areolar tissue; the fibrous layer, consisting of the tarsi and the orbital septum; the lid retractors of the upper and lower eyelids; the retroseptal fat pads; and the conjunctiva.

Sensory innervation of the eyelids is subserved by terminal branches of the ophthalmic (cranial nerve [CN] V1) and maxillary (CN V2) divisions of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Within the superior orbit, the frontal branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve travels anteriorly between the periorbita of the roof and the levator muscle. Midway along the roof, it divides into a larger supraorbital nerve and a smaller supratrochlear nerve. Terminal branches of these nerves supply sensation to the upper eyelid and forehead

Contents.Introduction: The anterior chamber (AC) is the fluid-filled space inside the eye between the iris and the innermost surface of the cornea, the endothelium.
Contents.Aqueous Humour: Aqueous humor is the fluid that fills the anterior chamber.

Contents.Dosage: Recommended doses of acetazolamide vary depending on the condition being treated and the circumstances. For glaucoma, the usual recommended dose is 250 mg by mouth 1 to 4 times a day
Contents.Side Effects:
Acetazolamide may cause the following side effects.

Confusion
Diarrhea
Drowsiness
Increased urination
Loss of appetite
Malaise (generally feeling of discomfort)
Metallic taste
Nausea or vomiting
Blood in urine
Dark-coloured stools
Fever
Hives
Rash
Red or purple spots on the skin
Ringing in ears or hearing loss
Tingling feeling in fingers and toes
Contents.Contraindications: Acetazolamide is contraindicated in known allergy to the medication, hyponatremia and hypokalemia and in those with severe kidney or liver dysfunction. This medication passes into breast milk.

Contents.MOA: Quinolones bind to DNA Gyrase and prevent them from decatenation replicating DNA.
Contents.Dosage: Each 1 mL of eye drops contains 3.5 mg of ciprofloxacin hydrochloride quivalent to 3 mg base (0.3%).
Contents.Contraindications:
Ciprofloxacin eye drop solution should not be used by anyone who:

- is allergic to ciprofloxacin or to any of the ingredients of the medication
- is allergic to nalidixic acid or other quinolones (e.g., norfloxacin, levofloxacin, and ofloxacin)

Contents.MOA: Prednisolone irreversibly binds with glucocorticoid receptors (GR) alpha and beta for which they have a high affinity that leads to suppression of inflammation and also the immune response.
Contents.Dosage: The recommended dose of prednisolone acetate eye drops varies depending on the condition being treated and is typically tapered weekly. Each mL of suspension contains: prednisolone acetate 1%
Contents.Indications:
Stromal HSV keratitis
Allergic Eye Disease
Vernal Kerato-conjunctivitis - VKC
Post-Operative Inflammation control
Marginal Keratitis.
Contents.Side Effects: The drug can cause a rise in the Intraocular pressure in steroid responders and IOP must be checked 2 weeks after starting the drug.
Contents.Contraindications:
Prednisolone acetate eye drops are contraindicated if

-  are allergic to prednisolone or any ingredients of the medication
-  have had an allergic or sensitivity reaction to other corticosteroids
-  have acute herpes simplex, tuberculosis of the eye, vaccinia, chickenpox, or other viral or fungal diseases of the eye
-  have any eye infection associated with discharge
-  have conjunctivitis or blepharitis associated with discharge
-  have recently had a foreign body removed from the eye.

Contents.MOA: It is a competitive antagonist for the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor types M1, M2, M3, M4 and M5. It is classified as an anticholinergic drug (parasympatholytic).
Contents.Dosage: Each 1 mL of ophthalmic solution contains 1% Atropine Sulfate.
Contents.Indications: Topical atropine is used as a cycloplegic, to temporarily paralyze the accommodation reflex and as a mydriatic, to dilate the pupils. Atropine degrades slowly, typically wearing off in 7 to 14 days. Atropine induces mydriasis by blocking contraction of the circular pupillary sphincter muscle and dilates the pupil. Atropine induces cycloplegia by paralyzing the ciliary muscles, whose action inhibits accommodation to allow accurate refraction in children, helps to relieve pain associated with iridocyclitis, and treats ciliary block (malignant) glaucoma.
Contents.Side Effects: A common mnemonic used to describe them is: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter". These associations reflect the specific changes of warm, dry skin from decreased sweating, blurry vision, decreased sweating⁄lacrimation, vasodilation, and central nervous system effects on muscarinic receptors, type 4 and 5 collectively known as anticholinergic toxidrome.
Contents.Contraindications: Atropine is contraindicated in patients pre-disposed to narrow angle glaucoma and if allergic to the medication.
Contents.History: Mandragora (mandrake) was described by Theophrastus in the fourth century B.C. for treatment of wounds, gout, and sleeplessness, and as a love potion. Atropine extracts from the Egyptian henbane were used by Cleopatra in the last century B.C. to dilate her pupils, in the hope that she would appear more alluring. In the Renaissance, women used the juice of the berries of Atropa belladonna to enlarge the pupils of their eyes, for cosmetic reasons.

Contents.MOA: Chloramphenicol is a bacteriostatic drug that stops bacterial growth by inhibiting protein synthesis. Chloramphenicol prevents protein chain elongation by inhibiting the peptidyl transferase activity of the bacterial ribosome. It specifically binds to A2451 and A2452 residues in the 23S rRNA of the 50S ribosomal subunit, preventing peptide bond formation
Contents.Dosage: Each 1 mL of ophthalmic solution contains 0.5% Chloramphenicol.
Contents.Indications: Chloramphenicol has a broad spectrum of activity and has been effective in treating ocular infections caused by a number of bacteria including Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli. Chloramphenicol is not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Contents.Side Effects: The most serious side effect of chloramphenicol treatment is aplastic anaemia. The lowest risk occurs with eye drops (affecting less than 1 in 224,716 prescriptions). Topical application to eyes has been associated with mercurialentis and atypical band keratopathy.

Contents.Dosage: Each 1 mL of ophthalmic solution, 0.15% contains brimonidine tartrate 1.5 mg and 0.2% contains brimonidine tartrate 2 mg.
Contents.MOA:
Brimonidine is an α2 adrenergic agonist.

Alpha 2 agonists, through the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor, inhibit the activity of adenylate cyclase. This reduces cAMP and hence aqueous humour production by the ciliary body.
Contents.Indications: Brimonidine is indicated for the lowering of intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension. It is also the active ingredient of Combigan along with timolol maleate.
Contents.Contraindications:
Brimonidine eye drops are contraindicated if

allergic to brimonidine or to any of the ingredients of the medication
using monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI)

Contents.Dosage: Each 1 mL of ophthalmic solution contains Olopatadine hydrochloride 0.1%.
Contents.MOA: Olopatadine hydrochloride is an antihistamine (as well as anticholinergic and mast cell stabilizer)
Contents.Indications: It is used to treat itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis
Contents.Side Effects: Some known side effects include headache (7% of occurrence), eye burning and⁄or stinging (5%), blurred vision, dry eyes, foreign body sensation, hyperemia, keratitis, eyelid edema,pruritus, asthenia, sore throat (pharyngitis), rhinitis, sinusitis, and taste perversion.

Contents.Dosage: Each drop of sterile ophthalmic solution contains approximately 0.04 mL of the 2% solution or sodium cromoglycate 0.8 mg.
Contents.MOA: Cromolyn works because it prevents the release of mediators that would normally attract inflammatory cells and because it stabilizes the inflammatory cells and is a mast cell stabilizer. It may act by inhibiting calcium influx.
Contents.Indications: It is used to treat itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis
Contents.Contraindications:
Cromoglycate eye drops are contraindicated if

        allergic to cromoglycate or to any of the ingredients of the medication

Contents.Dosage: Each 1 ml of sterile ophthalmic solution contains Loteprednol Etabonate INN 5 mg.
Contents.MOA: Loteprednol is a corticosteroid which is thought to act by the induction of phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins, which control the biosynthesis of potent mediators of inflammation such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes by inhibiting the release of their common precursor arachidonic acid.
Contents.Indications: ocular applications for this drug include the treatment of inflammation of the eye due to allergies (according to the prescription information sheet), as well as chronic forms of keratitis (e.g.adenoviral and Thygeson's keratitis), vernal keratoconjunctivitis, pingueculitis, andepiscleritis. The drug has little or no effect on intraocular pressure.
Contents.Side Effects: It has no or little effect on the Intraocular Pressure.
Contents.Contraindications:
Loteprednol eye drops are contraindicated if

allergic to lotepred or to any of the ingredients of the medication
Bacterial diseases of the Conjunctiva and Cornea

Contents.Dosage:
Each 1 mL of 0.5% sterile ophthalmic solution contains Timolol Maleate BP equivalent to Timolol basic 5 mg.

For ophthalmic use, timolol is also available combined with other medications:

• Combigan - timolol and brimonidine
• Iotim-B - timolol and brimonidine
• Cosopt - timolol maleate and dorzolamide             hydrochloride
• DuoTrav - timolol and travoprost
• Xalacom - timolol and latanoprost
Contents.MOA: Timolol maleate is a non-selective beta-adrenergic receptor antagonist
Contents.Contraindications: Absolute bronchial asthma, bronchospasm, history of bronchial asthma or severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Uncontrolled congestive cardiac insufficiency, cardiogenic shock High atrioventricular block (without apparatus) Raynaud phenomena, High bradycardia (pulse rate < 45 to 50 pulses⁄min.), Hypersensitivity to any component, relative combination with amiodarone.

Contents.Mackie Classification:
Used to classify Neurotrophic Keratitis.


Stage 1
Punctate epithelial staining
Decreased tear breakup test
Rose Bengal staining of Inferior palpebral conjunctiva
Dellen
Gaule spots
Stromal scarring


Stage 2
Epithelial defect
Stromal swelling
Surrounding rim of loose epithelium
Rare anterior chamber reaction


Stage 3
Corneal ulcer
Stromal lysis
Perforation.

Contents.Ptosis Evaluation:
Lid Evaluation –

Upper lid height and position in relation to the globe and is normally 2-3 mm covering the limbus.

Marginal reflex distance 1 (MRD-1)
With the eye in primary gaze position, the distance measured between the center of the pupillary light reflex and the upper eyelid margin is called MRD-1 and normally is 3-4 mm.

Marginal reflex distance 2 (MRD-2)
With the eye in primary gaze position, the distance between the center of the pupillary light reflex and the lower eyelid margin is called MRD-2 and normally is 7-9 mm.

Documentation of the presence of eyelid crease and its height is important.

Levator function is assessed by inactivating the action of the frontalis muscle at the brow and then assessing the distance the eyelid travels from downgaze to upgaze. Ptosis can be subdivided based on this function into Severe (LPS action <5mm), Moderate )LPS action 6 - 10mm ), Mild (LPS action >10mm) .Must also look for -
Ocular Motility
Ocular Motility
Head Tilt
Chin Elevation
Marcus Jaw Winking phenomenon
Previous eyelid scars

Additional Tests -
Fatigue Test and Ice Pack Test to rule out Myasthenia Gravis.

Contents.Van Hericks Technique:
A narrow slit of light is projected onto the peripheral cornea at an angle of 60Â° as near as possible to the limbus. This results in slit images of the corneal thickness and the peripheral anterior chamber depth (PACD).



Reference
Van Herick W, Shaffer RN, Schwartz A: Estimation of width of angle of anterior chamber. Incidence and significance of the narrow angle. American Journal of Ophthalmology 1969; 68: 626-629

Contents.Fundus examination:
The fundus can be examined in the non dilated or dilated state. The various instruments used are an Indirect Ophthalmoscope, a Direct Ophthalmoscope and use of lenses of 78D, 90D and 20D in conjunction with the Slit Lamp.

Order of description -
Media - Whether clear or Hazy?

Optic Disc - Size
Shape
Color
Margins
Cup/Disc/ratio
Look for-Nerve Fiber Layer defect
Disc Haemorrhage
Drusen

Vessels -A:V Ratio
Constriction
Vascular Tortuosity

Macula - Foveal Reflex-

Periphery can be examined using an Indirect Ophthalmoscope and Indenting with a Thimble or a sterile Cotton Bud

Contents.REPOrT:
REPOrT was started on July 8th, 2008 at Kanapuram Village, Warangal. It stands for Rural Education and Prevention of Ocular Trauma. It specifically targets the need to prevent Ocular Trauma, more so in the Rural Areas and also urban too among children and adults.

REPOrT has since then addressed over 20,300 school children, 150 Teachers and 25 PHC workers in various villages in Andhra Pradesh, India. It is an ongoing project and uses the P.A.T Strategy to combat Ocular injuries.

The P.A.T Strategy of REPOrT includes -

- Prevention
- Analyze
- Treat

Effective prevention projects on the ground with specific focus on local risk factors, Analyze the burden of ocular trauma with the state-of-the art Electronic Medical Record system (EyeSmart EMR) and treat the injuries with the latest surgical techniques and based on scientific research is the vision of REPOrT.

It is being currently expanded in the rural areas in the entire LVPEI Network.

Find out more about REPOrT - Click Here

1886,Geelong, Victoria, Australia;

Adie’s syndrome = A condition in which one or both pupils is dilated and responds slowly or not at all to light and a near stimulus, accompanied by slow constriction and relaxation in the change from near to distant vision, and impaired accommodation.

Amsler grid through an eye with macular degeneration

Amsler’s sign - Haemorrhage caused by applanation tonometry and cataract surgery in Fuch’s heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI). It was once thought to be pathognomonic for FHI, was previously used as a diagnostic and confirmatory test in patients with suspected FHI.

Headers: Douglas Moray Cooper Lamb Argyll Robertson

Contents.Douglas Moray Cooper Lamb Argyll Roberts:
Scottish ophthalmologist,

Born 1837, Edinburgh

Died 3rd January, 1909,

Gonday near Bombay, India


Eponym

Argyll Robertson’s syndrome - A frequent symptom of neurosyphilis, especially tabes dorsalis, and other diseases of thecentral nervous system, in which the pupil is small and responds slowly or not at all to light, but reaction to accommodation and convergence is retained.

Douglas Moray Cooper Lamb Argyll Robertson was one of the first surgeons to specialize entirely in the field of ophthalmology and his name has been forever associated with the phenomenon he described in the pupil found in tabes dorsalis.

Eponym

Arlt’s Line - Horizontal, linear scarring of the upper tarsal conjunctiva. A classical sign of trachoma.Arlt described an operation for transplantation of the ciliary bulbs in the treatment of distichiasis. In his work on the diseases of the eye he presented the proof that short-sightedness is normally a consequence of an elongation of the sagittal diameter of the bulbus of the eye.

Cogan’s sign -Cogan’s lid twitch, in patients with myasthenia. When the patient’s eyes are directed downward for 10 to 20 seconds and the patient is then instructed to make a vertical saccade back to primary position, the upper eyelid elevates and either slowly begins to droop or else twitches several times before settling into a stable position

Cogan-Reese disease - A syndrome characterized by a matted or smudged appearance to the surface of the iris, unilateral glaucoma in the eyes with multiple peripheral anterior synechiae, multiple nodules of the iris, and ectopic Descemet’s membrane.

Cogan’s syndrome- Syndrome of interstitial keratitis characterized by abrupt onset of vertigo, tinnitus, and usually rapid development of bilateral deafness.

Duane’s retraction syndrome is frequently mistaken for a sixth-nerve palsy in infancy because of deficient abduction of the involved eye. In fact, as a cause of limited abduction Duane’s syndrome is quite common in children, so it must be kept in mind.

Groenouw-Fleischer dystrophy = A peculiar form of an inheritable, parenchymatous nodular degeneration of cornea, a corneal dystrophy characterized by hyaline degeneration in the absence of acid mucopolysaccharide deposition.

Kayser-Fleischer ring = Ring of grey-green or brownish-pigmented ring, 1-3 mm broad, in the deep epithelial layers at the outer border of the cornea. Pathogonomic eye symptom due to copper deposition in Wilson's disease (degeneratio hepatolenticularis).

Contents.Jules Fran&ccedil;ois:
Belgian Ophthalmologist

Born 24th May, 1907

Jules François studied medicine at the University of Louvain, graduating in 1930. He commenced a private ophthalmologic practice in Charleroi, while also conducting scientific work. This eventually led to his appointment as professor of ophthalmology at the University of Ghent, where he established a modern ophthalmological department. Jules François published more than 1000 articles. He was an officer of the Order of Leopold II and a chevalier of the Légion d'Honneur.

Fuchs' heterochromic cyclitis = An idiopathic disorder of the eye, with heterochromia, uveitis of the lighter coloured eye, iridocyclitis, keratitic precipitates and often catarct.

Fuchs' spot = A small black spot on the fundus in high myopia, occurring after macular haemorrhage.

Contents.Carl von Hess:
German Ophthalmologist

Born 1863

Died 1923


Eponym

Hess chart = Carl von Hess was professor of ophthalmology first at Marburg in 1896, then at Wurzburg in 1900, and finally at Munich in 1912. His main interest is comparative ocular physiology.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Johann Friedrich Horner:
Swiss Ophthalmologist

Born 27th March, 1831
Zurich.

Died 20th December, 1886
Zurich.


Eponym

Horner's syndrome = A syndrome mainly characterised by a trias of miosis, ptosis, and enophthalmos.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Jonathan Hutchinson:
English Ophthalmologist

Born 1828

Died 1913


Eponym

Hutchinson's sign = Involvement of the tip of the nose from herpes zoster, a sign taken to indicate that the eye may be seriously involved by VZV because of the involvement of the nasal branch of the nasociliary nerve.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

German anatomist

Born 15th December, 1797
Hannover

Died 8th June, 1868
Hannover

Krause's glands = Accessory lacrimal glands.

Contents.Theodor Leber:
German Ophthalmologist

Born 29th February, 1840
Karlsruhe

Died 1917


Eponym

Leber's congenital amaurosis = Syndrome characterised by severe visual deficiency, with total or nearly total blindness, present at birth or shortly thereafter.

Leber=s miliary aneurysm = A form of unilateral exudative retinopathy occurring in children before puberty, it is now considered as a milder form of Coat's disease.

Leber's optic atrophy = A rare hereditary form of optic atrophy that usually affects young males.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Arvid Vilhelm Lindau:
Swedish Pathologist

Born 1892
Malmö

Died 1958


Eponym

Von Hippel-Lindau disease = A syndrome characterised by angiomatosis of the retina, haemangioblastoma of the cerebellum and walls of the fourth ventricle, commonly associated with polycystic lesions of the kidney and pancreas.

Von Hippel-Lindau tumour = A disturbance characterised by angiomata of the retina and cysts and angiomata of the brain and certain visceral organs.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Marcus Gunn:
Scotland

Born 1850
Dunnet

Died 1909
Hindhead


Eponym

Marcus Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon = unilateral eyelid movement with movement of the jaw.

Marcus Gunn pupil = relative afferent pupillary defect caused by optic nerve lesion or extensive retinal disease.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Antoine Bernard-Jean Marfan:
French Paediatrician

Born 23rd June, 1858
Castelnaudary, département Aude,Languedoc-Roussillon région

Died 1942


Eponym

Marfan's syndrome = A disorder of connective tissue affecting primarily the musculoskeletal system, the cardiovascular system and the eye with dislocation of the lens.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Johannes Freiherr von Mikulicz-Radecki:
Polish Surgeon

Born 16th May, 1850
Czernowitz, Bukowina, Romania

Died 4th June, 1905
Breslau, Germany


Eponym

Mikulicz's syndrome = Chronic dacryoadenitis with bilateral painless swelling of lacrimal and salivary glands and decreased or absent lacrimation. Seen in sarcoidosis, lymphoma and other infiltrative diseases.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Paul Julius M&ouml;bius:
German Neurologist

Born January 24, 1853
Leipzig

Died 1907
Leipzig


Eponym

Möbius's syndrome = A congenital syndrome characterized by congenital palsy of the external rectus and facial muscles, usually bilateral, associated with paralysis of the sixth and seventh nerves.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Morgagni:
Italian anatomist

Born 25 February 1682

Died 6 December 1771


Eponym

Morgagni's cataract = Hypermature cataract in which the cortex is liquefied leaving behind a brown nucleus that sinks to the bottom of the lens.

Contents.Henri Parinaud:
French ophthalmologist and neurologist

Born 1844

Died 1905


Eponym

Parinaud's syndrome = A dorsal midbrain lesion such as pinealoma which results in vertical gaze palsy, convergence-retraction nystagmus and light-near dissociation.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Jan Evangelista Purkinje &#40;Purkyne&#4:
Czech physician and neurophysiologist

Born 1787

Died 1869


Eponym

He was appointed as Professor of Physiology at the University of Prague, where he discovered the phenomenon known as the Pukinje effect (as light intensity decreases, red objects are perceived to fade faster than blue objects of the same brightness).

An early user of the improved compound microscope, he discovered the sweat glands of the skin in 1833, germinal vessicles in 1825, recognized fingerprints as a means of identification in 1823 and noted the protein-digesting power of pancreatic extracts in 1836.

Johannes Evangelista Purkinje was a pioneer to experimental physiology whose investigations in the fields of histology, embryology and pharmacology helped to create a modern understanding of the eye and vision, brain and heart function, mammalian reproduction and the composition of cells.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Othmar Purtscher:
Austrian Ophthalmologist

Born 1852

Died 1927


Eponym

Purtscher's retinopathy = patches of retinal whitening, retinal hemorrhages, and disc oedema after compression injury to the head. Patients may experience loss of vision in one or both eyes. Similar retinal abnormalities has been observed after severe compression injury to the chest.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Hans Conrad Julius Reiter:
German bacteriologist and hygienist

Born 26th February, 1881
Reudnitz near Leipzig

Died 1969
Hessen


Eponym

Reiter's syndrome = The classic triad consists of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis; other characteristic features include heel pain, skin and mucous membrane lesions, and bone changes. This condition typically affects young men who are HLA B 27 positive.

Click here to Read More

We would like to thank Prof.CN Chua for the kind permission to share this information.

Contents.Name: Prenticeâs Rule
Contents.Formula:
P = cf
where,

P = amount of prism correction in prism diopters

c = decentration (the distance between the pupil centre and the lensâs optical centre, in centimeters)

f = lens power in diopters
Contents.Use: To determine the amount of induced prism in a lens

Contents.Name: Focal Length
Contents.Use: To find out the focal length of a lens.

Contents.Name: Radius of Curvature
Contents.Formula:
RoC = (n-1)⁄diopters
where,

n = refractive index of the lens
Contents.Use: To find out the radius of curvature of a lens

Contents.Name: Brewster's angle
Contents.Use: This angle is angle of incidence where the reflected light is linearly polarized

Contents.Name: Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff (SRK) Formula
Contents.Formula:
D = A - 0.9K - 2.5L
where,

D = Power in Dioptres for Emmetropia

A = A constant for each type of intraocular lens

L = axial length in mm

K = average keratometer readings in diopters
Contents.Use: It is used to calculate Intraocular Lens (IOL) power for implantation in Cataract Surgery.
